{{Infobox film | name = L'arcidiavolo
The Devil in Love | image = L'arcidiavolo.jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Ettore Scola]] | producer = [[Mario Cecchi Gori]] | writer = | based_on = ''[[Belfagor arcidiavolo]]'' by [[Niccolò Machiavelli]] | starring = | music = [[Armando Trovajoli]] | cinematography = [[Aldo Tonti]] | editing = | distributor = | released = 1966 | runtime = | country = [[Italy]] | language = [[Italian language|Italian]] | budget = }} '''''The Devil in Love''''' ([[Italian language|Italian]]: '''''L'arcidiavolo''''') is a [[Italian films of 1966|1966]] [[Italy|Italian]] [[fantasy-comedy film]]. It stars [[Vittorio Gassman]] and [[Gabriele Ferzetti]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mymovies.it/filmografia/?a=73|title=Gabriele Ferzetti |publisher=[[Mymovies.it]]|accessdate=November 30, 2010}} It is loosely based on the tale ''[[Belfagor arcidiavolo]]'' by [[Niccolò Machiavelli]].{{cite web |url=https://www.mymovies.it/dizionario/recensione.asp?id=1958 |title=L'arcidiavolo |work=Mymovies.it |language=Italian |accessdate=6 April 2020 }} ==Cast== *[[Vittorio Gassman]] as [[Beelphegor|Belfagor]] *[[Claudine Auger]] as [[Maddalena di Lorenzo de' Medici|Maddalena de' Medici]] *[[Mickey Rooney]] as [[Adrammelech|Adramelek]] *[[Gabriele Ferzetti]] as [[Lorenzo de' Medici]] *[[Ettore Manni]] as Gianfigliazzo *[[Annabella Incontrera]] as Lucrezia *[[Hélène Chanel]] as [[Clarice Orsini]] *[[Milena Vukotic]] as Maddalena's waitress *[[Elena Fabrizi]] as Maddalena's waitress *[[Paolo Di Credico]] as [[Pope Leo X|Cardinal Giovanni de' Medici]] *[[Giorgia Moll]] as aristocrat's wife *[[Liana Orfei]] as Olimpia *[[Ugo Fangareggi]] as Lorenzo's biographer *[[Luigi Vannucchi]] as Prince [[Franceschetto Cybo]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{imdb title}} {{Ettore Scola}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Devil In Love (Film)}} [[Category:1966 films]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:Italian-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Florence]] [[Category:Films directed by Ettore Scola]] [[Category:Films scored by Armando Trovajoli]] [[Category:Films set in the 15th century]] [[Category:Italian fantasy comedy films]] [[Category:1960s fantasy-comedy films]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Lorenzo de' Medici]] [[Category:Adaptations of works by Niccolò Machiavelli]] [[Category:1966 comedy films]] {{1960s-Italy-comedy-film-stub}}

{{Infobox film awards |number=26 |award=Independent Spirit Awards |date=February 26, 2011 |site=U.S. |host=[[Joel McHale]] |best_film=''[[Black Swan (film)|Black Swan]]'' |most_wins=''Black Swan'' (4) |most_nominations=''[[Winter's Bone]]'' (7) |last=25th |next=27th }}
The '''26th [[Independent Spirit Awards]]''' announced its nominees in November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/independent_spirit_nominations_winters_bone_black_swan_the_kids_are_all_rig|title=Independent Spirit Nominations: Winter's Bone, Black Swan, The Kids Are All Right Head for Oscars|date=2010-11-30|work=indieWire|accessdate=2012-08-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221200130/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/independent_spirit_nominations_winters_bone_black_swan_the_kids_are_all_rig|archive-date=2014-02-21|url-status=dead|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/awards/2010/11/winters-bone-and-the-kids-are-all-right-top-the-spirit-award-nominations.html|title='Winter's Bone' and 'The Kids Are All Right' top the Spirit Award nominations|date=2010-11-30|work=The Envelope|accessdate=2012-08-25}}</ref> The winners were announced on February 26, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2011-02-26-indie-spirit-awards_N.htm|title='Black Swan' sweeps Film Independent Spirit Awards|date=2011-02-26|work=USA Today|accessdate=2011-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/spirits_2011_list_of_announced_spirit_award_winners_in_progess|title="Black Swan" Lead Spirit Award Winners|date=2011-02-27|work=indieWire|accessdate=2012-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/27/entertainment/la-et-spirit-awards-20110227|title='Black Swan' wins four Spirit Awards, including best feature and best actress|date=2011-02-27|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2012-08-25}}</ref> It was hosted by [[Joel McHale]].

population_density_sq_mi= | population_demonym = <!-- time zone(s) --> | timezone1 = [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] | utc_offset1 = -5 | timezone1_DST = | utc_offset1_DST = | timezone2 = | utc_offset2 = | timezone2_DST = | utc_offset2_DST = <!-- postal codes, area code --> | postal_code_type = Postal code | postal_code = 18036 | area_code_type = | area_code = [[Area code 610|610]] Exchange: 282 | geocode = | iso_code = <!-- website, footnotes --> | website = | footnotes = }} '''Locust Valley, Pennsylvania''' was a village located in the southeastern corner of [[Lehigh County, Pennsylvania|Lehigh County]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] at the southern end of [[Upper Saucon Township, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania|Upper Saucon Township]].<ref>https://www.openstreetmap.org/search?query=upper%20saucon%20pa#map=15/40.4963/-75.4042</ref> It developed around the crossroad of what is today, Locust Valley Road and Blue Church Road South.
This area is bordered by [[Springfield Township, Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Springfield Township]] and [[Milford Township, Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Milford Township]] in [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks County, PA]] along with [[Lower Milford Township, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania|Lower Milford Township]] in Lehigh County.
George W. Foering planted (in the mid-1800s) an avenue of [[locust tree]]s, thus the village name, Locust Valley. Locust trees are still prevalent in the area, including those on the Locust Valley [[golf course]].
Over time, Locust Valley lost its distinction as a village and now is part of the [[Coopersburg, PA]] mailing address.
== History of Settlement == This land was part of the area called [[Lenapehoking]] by the [[Lenape]] native people that inhabited it prior to the arrival of European settlers. The Unami were the specific division of the Lenape locally and they referred to this area as ''The Valley Watered by Many Springs.''
[[William Penn]] founded the colony of [[History of Pennsylvania|Pennsylvania]] in 1681 and this area was part of [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks County]], one of the three original counties created by Penn in 1682. The Lenape people were pushed farther west by the subsequent purchase of land by William Penn. A purchase in 1732 further secured the area of the Lehigh Valley.
German immigrants settled the Locust Valley area around 1735 calling it ''Die Gass'' (the valley). The local immigrants formally organized this area as [[Upper Saucon Township, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania|Upper Saucon Township]] in 1743.<ref>https://www.uppersaucon.org/township-info/history/</ref> At the founding of the township, Locust Valley was one of the 5 villages in the township, the others being [[Center Valley, Pennsylvania|Centre Valley]], Friedensville, Spring Valley and [[Colesville, Pennsylvania|Colesville]]. Then, in 1752, this area became part of newly created [[Northampton County, Pennsylvania|Northampton County]]. Since 1812, when Northampton County was divided into two, Locust Valley has been located in [[Lehigh County, Pennsylvania|Lehigh County]].
Warrants were given to the original settlers for purchase of plots of land. The first one in the Locust Valley area was given to Henry Rumfield in 1736 (tract #12). The plot (#14) warranted to George Morsteller in 1737 encompassed the hub of Locust Valley. Subsequent warrants (in chronological order) were given to John Adam Stout (#96), George Bachman (#11 & #97), George Bastian (#13), Cornelius Crump (#98), Jacob Weaver (#100), Leonard Boydelman (#142), Jacob Bachman (#143), and Peter Cortz (#144).
During the American Revolution, George Bachman was one of the residents that was imprisoned, banished and all of his property confiscated because he was reluctant to bear arms.
== Commerce == The village developed around an [[iron mill]] (P. Weaver Foundry<ref name = "map">Aschbach, G. A. ''Map of Lehigh County''. (1862). https://www.loc.gov/resource/g3823l.la000766/</ref>) that is located near the [[River source|headwaters]] of Laurel Run (South Branch of the [[Saucon Creek]]<ref>http://sauconcreekwatershed.org/images/maps/Assessment_Reaches.pdf</ref>). Laurel Run<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.fish.state.pa.us/fishpub/summary/troutregs_se.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-08-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011045556/http://www.fish.state.pa.us/fishpub/summary/troutregs_se.htm |archive-date=2014-10-11 |url-status=dead }}</ref> is a regulated trout stream in Pennsylvania. The [[mill race]] can still be seen as part of [http://www.locustvalleyclub.com/ Locust Valley Golf Course].
The village was once home to a post office, store (1870<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/642302056837/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref>) (W. Trumbaur Store<ref name = "map" />), hotel, school, and tavern.<ref name = "map" /> A tannery was still in operation in 1884.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Mathews |first1=Alfred |last2=Hungerford |first2=Austin N. |title=History of the Counties of Lehigh and Carbon, in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania |date=1884 |publisher=Everts & Richards |page=439 |url=https://www.google.com/search?tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=bibliogroup:%22History+of+the+Counties+of+Lehigh+and+Carbon,+in+the+Commonwealth+of+Pennsylvania%22&source=gbs_metadata_r&cad=6}}</ref>
An official road that ran from Locust Valley to Lanark opened in 1750.
In 1910, Frank G. Hartman and his brother-in-law, Harvey Hersh (who lived in Locust Valley), opened a foundry and machine shop called Hersh & Hartman. Frank brought twenty years of experience working at [[Bethlehem Steel|Bethlehem Steel Co.]], having worked there since age 16, into this new venture.<ref>{{cite book |first=Charles Rhoads |last=Roberts |first2=John Baer |last2=Stoudt |first3=Thomas H. |last3=Krick |first4=William Joseph |last4=Dietrich |title=History of Lehigh County, Pennsylvania, and a Genealogical and Biographical Record of Its Families |volume=II |date=1914 |publisher=Lehigh Valley publishing Company |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mzQPAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA506 |page=506}}</ref>
The Locust Valley [[Post Office]] was established on February 4, 1863. It was run by Peter Weaver out of the building (1832<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/642302232033/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref>) on the southwest corner of the village crossroads. This continued until [[Rural Free Delivery]] service was initiated.<ref>Upper Saucon Township – A Bicentennial Tribute 1743 – 1976 p. 128</ref>
In 1954, Locust Valley Country Club was granted a charter and opened on Memorial Day as a 9 hole private club. The 1806, 16 room [[fieldstone]] house and 125 acre property (which now spans Bucks and Lehigh Counties) was purchased from the Donald Smith estate.<ref>https://www.uppersaucon.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/UpperSauconHistory.pdf</ref> William F. Gordon was the designer of the course.<ref>https://asgca.org/architect/wfgordon/</ref> He also designed one of the courses at [[Saucon Valley Country Club]]. In 1985, Locust Valley became a public course. Baseball legends [[Joe DiMaggio]], [[Bob Feller]], [[Brooks Robinson]] and [[Bobby Thomson]] and Pro Football Hall of Famer [[Chuck Bednarik]] played in a tournament in 1986. [[Arnold Palmer]] was known to practice at Locust Valley since his first wife, Winnie Walzer, was from Coopersburg.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcall.com/sports/golf/mc-spt-locut-valley-golf-course-closing-date-20191030-4dtna22yhzhmlghck7ysbbelju-story.html|title=Last chance to play Locust Valley: Popular golf course open until April 2020|last=Wogenrich|first=Mark|website=mcall.com|access-date=2019-11-03}}</ref> The original 1806 home was razed in 2017.
== Schools == [[File:Locust Valley Schoolhouse 2019.jpg|thumb|2019 photo of the Locust Valley Schoolhouse built in 1880]] A one-room schoolhouse was first opened in 1850 two years after the township adopted the [[common school]] system. The school was about one-half mile directly north on what is now Blue Church Rd South. Prior to this, students were educated in private homes or churches (there was a school at the Blue Church, for example). The education was conducted in German exclusively until about 1800, before beginning to transition toward English.
Replacing the first building, a new schoolhouse was opened in 1880<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/641393470006/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref> with a tower and bell being added in 1902. <ref>http://mcall.newspapers.com/image/274818061</ref> In 1884, the school was furnished with a blackboard, globe and patent desks.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Mathews |first1=Alfred |last2=Hungerford |first2=Austin N. |title=History of the Counties of Lehigh and Carbon, in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania |date=1884 |publisher=Everts & Richards |page=433 |url=https://www.google.com/search?tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=bibliogroup:%22History+of+the+Counties+of+Lehigh+and+Carbon,+in+the+Commonwealth+of+Pennsylvania%22&source=gbs_metadata_r&cad=6}}</ref>
This school operated until 1941 when the district became more centralized and children were bused to larger community schools. In 1946, there were 3 buses serving the township, and the Locust Valley students were transported to the Lanark School (the other township school being the Center Valley School (1940)<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/642415065746/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref>).<ref>http://mcall.newspapers.com/image/275190367 The Morning Call August 28, 1946</ref> The Lanark School was built in 1941 and was located in the northern part of the township, on the east side of Rt 309.<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/641532835329/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref> Most recently a [https://www.flblaw.com/ law firm] has occupied the building with an address of Schoolhouse Lane.
The Locust Valley schoolhouse was auctioned off and remodeled into a residence.<ref>http://mcall.newspapers.com/image/279872836 Morning Call December 3, 1950</ref> This building is still in existence as a residential home at the intersection of Blue Church Rd S and Beverly Hills Rd.<ref>http://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment/SearchRecords</ref>
As time went along, before there were local junior and senior high schools, those that wanted further schooling would attend the schools in Allentown. Later, the local school district was developed into the [[Southern Lehigh School District]].
== Churches == Worship would have initially been conducted in homes or other gathering spots before specific structures were built. The first designated building for worship was the [[Mennonites|Mennonite]] meetinghouse in Coopersburg, built about 1738.
The next church constructed within the Upper Saucon area was St. Paul's Blue Church. The first church, built of logs, was in use by 1742. Later, the Friedens church, the Mennonite Brethren in Christ church, the English Methodist church and the Free Methodist churches were constructed.
== Notable Inhabitants == George Washington Foering (1812-1880) settled in Locust Valley about 1839. His home was on the north side of Locust Valley Rd east of Blue Church.<ref name="map" /> Mr. Foering was instrumental in the development of the Friedensville Zinc mines and was active politically. Being a supporter of [[James Buchanan]] for president, Mr. Foering welcomed Buchanan as a visitor in Locust Valley. A supporter of [[Abraham Lincoln]], Mr. Foering worked in Washington, DC during his administration and also assisted in various ways to enlist volunteers for the Union, including speaking throughout Lehigh County. He is buried in the Blue Church (Woodlands) cemetery.<ref>{{cite book |first=Charles Rhoads |last=Roberts |first2=John Baer |last2=Stoudt |first3=Thomas H. |last3=Krick |first4=William Joseph |last4=Dietrich |title=History of Lehigh County, Pennsylvania, and a Genealogical and Biographical Record of Its Families |volume=II |date=1914 |publisher=Lehigh Valley publishing Company |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mzQPAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA369 |page=369}}</ref><ref>https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/135336053/george-w_-foering</ref>
== Other Notable Properties == [[File:Locust Valley 1850 Home.jpg|thumb|1850 Locust Valley Home across from schoolhouse]] The (oldest?) home still standing is southwest of the crossroads, built in 1750.<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/642302124248/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref>
A fieldstone farmhouse was built in 1850<ref name="lehighcounty.org">https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/641393168578/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref> at the corner of Blue Church Road South and Beverly Hills Rd (catty-corner from the schoolhouse). This home design shows the German design influence (only 4-across exterior bays with 2 rooms on the first floor) on the [[Federal architecture|Federal style]] (symmetrical design; arch window above door).<ref>http://www.phmc.state.pa.us/portal/communities/architecture/styles/pa-german.html</ref> Originally, this house had a stucco exterior.
The third home, on the southwest corner of the T-intersection of Blue Church Rd S and Beverly Hills Rd was constructed in 1880.<ref name="lehighcounty.org"/>
Built in 1850,<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/641393248581/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref> the brick home across from the schoolhouse is built in the more traditional Federal style.
The home at the northeast corner of Locust Valley and Gun Club road was built in 1820.<ref>https://www.lehighcounty.org/Departments/Assessment-Home/Assessment-Direct/PIN/642313587338/PAR/1/handshake/92C43C17-974A-45F5-8090-224744361AC9</ref>
==References== Hauser, James J. ''A history of Lehigh County, Pennsylvania, from the earliest settlements to the present time, including much valuable information for the use of schools, families, libraries''. Jacks, The Printer, (1902), p. 47. https://archive.org/details/historyoflehighc00hause, Also referenced here: http://www.lehighvalleyhistory.com/the-history-of-upper-saucon-township/, and here: http://www.livingplaces.com/PA/Lehigh_County/Upper_Saucon_Township/Locust_Valley.html

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox ice hockey player | name = Ryan Flynn | image = | caption = | image_size = 230px | played_for = [[Milwaukee Admirals]]
[[HC Bolzano]]
[[Ilves]] | position = [[Winger (ice hockey)|Right Wing]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1988|03|22}} | birth_place = [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]], [[Minnesota]], U.S. | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 3 | weight_lb = 209 | shoots = Left | draft = 176th overall | draft_team = [[Nashville Predators]] | draft_year = 2006 | career_start = 2010 | career_end = 2014 }} '''Ryan Flynn''' (born March 22, 1988) is an [[United States|American]] former professional [[ice hockey]] player. He most notably played with [[Ilves]] of the Finnish [[Liiga]]. He was selected by the [[Nashville Predators]] in the 6th round (176th overall) of the [[2006 NHL Entry Draft]]. ==Playing career== Prior to turning professional, Flynn attended the [[University of Minnesota]] where he played four seasons with the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's ice hockey]] team which competes in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] in the [[Western Collegiate Hockey Association|WCHA]] conference.{{cite web|url=http://predators.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=523720|title=Nashville Predators Team News|publisher=}} Flynn began his professional career with the [[Milwaukee Admirals]] of the [[American Hockey League]].[http://www.clarksvilleonline.com/2011/09/25/nashville-predators-reduce-training-camp-roster-to-33/ Nashville Predators reduce Training Camp Roster to 33 » Clarksville, TN Online] For the 2012–13 season he played in [[Elite.A|Italy]] with [[HC Bolzano]], scoring 28 goals and 20 assists for 48 points in 42 games played, and on September 7, 2013, it was announced that Flynn would be joining [[Ilves]] to play in the Finnish [[SM-liiga]].{{cite web|url=http://ilves.com/?p=15292|title=Voimahyökkaajä Ryan Flynn Ilvekseen|work=www.Ilves.com}} ==International play== Flynn competed at the [[2006 IIHF World U18 Championships]] where he won a gold medal as a member of Team USA.{{cite web|url=http://www.nahl.com/news/story.cfm?id=203|title=USA Hockey announces World Junior team|work=North American Hockey League (NAHL)}} ==Career statistics== ===Regular season and playoffs=== {| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:center; width:60em" |- bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! colspan="3" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! colspan="5" | [[Regular season]] ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! colspan="5" | [[Playoffs]] |- bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! {{short description|Bangladeshi metal band}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Artcell | background = group_or_band | image = Artcell (57).jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Artcell at a live concert | origin = [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] | genre = {{hlist|[[Progressive metal]]|[[progressive rock]]}} | years_active = 1999–present | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Aurthohin]]|[[Warfaze]]|[[Cryptic Fate]]|[[Rockstrata]]|[[Nemesis (Bangladeshi band)|Nemesis]]|[[Arbovirus (band)|Arbovirus]]|Powersurge|AvoidRafa|Bay of Bengal}} | label = {{hlist|[[G-Series (record label)|G-Series]]}} | website = | current_members = * George Lincoln D'costa * Kazi Faisal Ahmed * Saef Al Nazi Cezanne * Kazi Shazzadul Asheqeen Shaju | past_members = * Ershad Zaman
}} '''Artcell''' is a Bangladeshi [[progressive metal]] band formed in October 1999 by vocalist and riff guitarist George Lincoln D'Costa, lead guitarist Ershad Zaman, bassist Saef Al Nazi Cezanne and drummer Kazi Sazzadul Asheqeen Shaju. Since 1999, they have released only two studio albums and also have appeared in some mixed albums. The four original members of the band remained together until Ershad Zaman left the band in 2017 due to his personal disagreement. They pronounced Kazi Faisal Ahmed as their permanent lead guitarist on 11 November 2018.<ref name=bracrev>{{cite web |url=http://www.bracnet.net/default.aspx?si=default&debug=&xid=749&m=web |title=Band Review – Artcell |publisher=www.bracnet.net |accessdate=30 November 2010 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004152710/http://www.bracnet.net/default.aspx?si=default&debug=&xid=749&m=web |archivedate=4 October 2011 }}</ref> According to [[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]], Artcell is one of the leading bands of the country.<ref name=DS>{{cite news |last=Mahmud |first=Jamil |date=24 October 2009 |title=A decade of Rock 'n' Roll |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=111139 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)]] |accessdate=30 November 2010 }}</ref>
==History== ===Formation and Early Days (1999-2000)=== Prior to forming the band, the four founding members were school friends from [[Dhaka]], and used to get together to play [[Metallica]] songs. Eventually, Ershad came up with compositions of his own and the group began to play them at shows. The positive response they received led them to the formation of a band. What started off as an [[underground band]] is now one of the most recognised mainstream bands in the [[Bengali people|Bengali]] metal music scene.<ref name=bracrev/>
The name "Artcell" was decided upon because it was softer sounding than a typical heavy metal name. In Cézanne and Shaju's words:
{{Blockquote|Even though we were a heavy metal band when we started, we didn't want a heavy metal name. We wanted a softer or an artistic touch to the heavy metal side. 'Cells where art is produced' – that was pretty much the basic idea behind the name 'Artcell.' Ershad came up with it and we all opted for it.}}
=== "অন্য সময় (Onno Somoy)" (2000–2002) === Artcell released their first studio album ''[[Onno Shomoy|অন্য সময় (Other Time)]]'' in 2002 by [[G-Series (record label)|G-Series]]. It was both critically and commercially successful.<ref name="tartareandesire">{{cite web |url=http://www.tartareandesire.com/bands/Artcell/10794/ |title= – Artcell – Heavy metal band from Bangladesh |website=Tartarean Desire |access-date=30 November 2010}}</ref> The band lost its main songwriter Rupok to [[Malaria|cerebral malaria]] while working on this album. The album was dedicated to him. One of the songs was titled "রুপক একটি গান (Rupok A Song)" in his memory.
=== "অনিকেত প্রান্তর (Oniket Prantor)" (2002–2006) === After the success of ''[[Onno Shomoy|অন্য সময়]]'', Artcell spent four years carrying out experiments with their music without releasing an album. They did, however, release singles scattered in various albums by other bands or [[compilation albums]]. Their second studio album "Aniket Prantor (No man's land)" was released in April 2006. The album was one of the top sellers of the year.<ref name="tartareandesire" />
"Aniket Prantor (No man's land)", the album's namesake, is Artcell's longest song to date, at 16 minutes and 21 seconds.<ref>{{cite news |last=Karim |first=Elita |date=21 April 2006 |title=Music to my ears... |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/magazine/2006/04/03/music.htm |work=Star Weekend Magazine |publisher=The Daily Star |accessdate=30 November 2010 }}</ref>
In May the band performed their second solo concert at Dhaka's Bashundhara Convention Centre.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rahman |first=Zeeshan B. |date=18 May 2006 |title=The week in re(ar)view: Artcell live in concert |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/rising/2006/05/03/switch.htm |work=Rising Stars |publisher=The Daily Star |accessdate=30 November 2010 }}</ref>
===2007-2016=== [[File:Sheraton Hotel.JPG|right|thumb|The Dhaka Sheraton, where the "10 Years of Artcell Insanity" concert took place]] [[Image:Artcell (59).jpg|right|thumb|Ershad with Jewel (Miles) at 10 Years of Artcell Insanity concert]]
Artcell celebrated its 10th anniversary tour on 23 October 2009 with a live concert entitled "10 Years of Artcell Insanity" at the Winter Garden, Dhaka Sheraton Hotel.<ref name=DS/><ref>{{cite news |last=Alamgir |first=Mohiuddin |date=23 October 2009 |title=Artcell celebrates its tenth year |url=http://www.weeklyholiday.net/2009/231009/cul.html |url-status=dead |newspaper=Holiday |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720024338/http://www.weeklyholiday.net/2009/231009/cul.html |archive-date=20 July 2011 |access-date=30 November 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Artcell tribute concert held |url=http://www.dhakamirror.com/?p=9764#more-9764 |newspaper=Dhaka Mirror |date=25 October 2009 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130121125443/http://www.dhakamirror.com/art-culture/artcell-tribute-concert-held/ |archive-date=21 January 2013 |access-date=30 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=Culture News: Artcell celebrates through concert |url=http://www.dhakacourier.net/issue15/report/doc2.html |magazine=Dhaka Courier Online |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723091920/http://www.dhakacourier.net/issue15/report/doc2.html |archive-date=23 July 2011 |access-date=30 November 2010}}</ref>
Artcell continue to regularly perform live shows and have also made many tours of [[Dhaka]], [[Chittagong]], [[Khulna]], [[Rajshahi]] and [[Sylhet]], with some tours in [[India]] and [[Sydney|Sydney, Australia]].
In 2009 the band took part in the "International Coastal Cleanup 2009", a day-long beach clean-up movement, at the [[Cox's Bazar]] sea beach.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/search_index.php?news_id=76218&page=detail_news |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305061233/http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/search_index.php?news_id=76218&page=detail_news |url-status=dead |archive-date=5 March 2012 |title=AB Bank celebrates 'Int'l Coastal Cleanup-'09' |date=16 August 2009 |newspaper=The Financial Express |location=Dhaka |accessdate=30 November 2010}}</ref>
In early 2010, the band travelled to Australia and performed at [[Belmore Sports Ground]] in Sydney on 3 January.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://banglamusic.com/articles/artcell-goes-places-3612.html#more-3612 |title=Artcell goes places |publisher=Bangla Music |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101101135023/http://banglamusic.com/articles/artcell-goes-places-3612.html |archive-date= 1 November 2010 |access-date=30 November 2010 }}</ref> The band was due to be one of the country's leading bands to perform at a concert against violence to women in the Banani Army Stadium, Dhaka, in December 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=UNFPA, BAMBA to host concert |url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/more.php?page=detail_news&news_id=118683&date=2010-11-29 |newspaper=The Financial Express |location=Dhaka |date=29 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305061411/http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/more.php?page=detail_news&news_id=118683&date=2010-11-29 |archive-date=5 March 2012 |access-date=30 November 2010 }}</ref>
On 9 January 2012, Artcell announced the release of their third album and confirmed that it would be released by the end of the year. They posted on their Facebook page: "This is to inform all Artcell fans and friends who have been waiting for our 3rd album, wait just for a few more months and Hopefully you won't be disappointed. In addition Artcell is also getting ready with some special releases...Music, videos and communication contents. So, look forward to a year full of activities. Thank you all again for your love and support. You guys are our true strength. Thank you".
Artcell worked on their third album in 2013.
They played in "Rocknation Overload" on 19 April 2014 after a break of around two years.
Cézanne and Shaju, two of the founding members, have not been active with the band for a long time. They only work with the band when they come to Bangladesh. The official Artcell website says that both of them have settled in Sydney, Australia, for family reasons. Ershad And Lincoln are presently running the band themselves with guest members.
In 2016, Artcell released their new music video "Obimrishshota" from their third album ''Otriteeyo'' with the original band lineup. After almost 10 years their new song had been released, written by their new lyricist Ishtiak. Both Cézanne and Shaju remain in Sydney, but they participated in the album work. Cézanne recently said in an interview that he is planning to be back in the country soon.
In the 17 years since its inception, the band has released two albums. Their third album was scheduled to be released in December 2016. Initially scheduled for a 2012 release, it is widely speculated that the delay is due to Cézanne and Shaju's inactivity, and to Ershad and Lincoln's busy schedule.
== Members ==
=== Present members === * Lincoln De Costa – [[vocals]], [[guitars]] {{small|(1999-present)}} * Kazi Faisal Ahmed – [[lead guitars]] {{small|(2018-present)}} * Saef Al Nazi Cezanne – [[bass guitar|bass]] {{small|(1999-present)}} * Kazi Shazzadul Asheqeen Shaju – [[drums]] {{small|(1999-present)}}
=== Touring members === * Sheikh Reaz – [[Drums]] {{small|(2010–present)}} * Niaz Kamran Abir - [[Drums]] {{small|(2014-2015)}} * Titas Baha – [[Bass guitar]]s {{small|(2018-present)}}
==Discography==
===Studio albums=== * ''[[Onno Shomoy|অন্য সময়]]'' (2002) * ''অনিকেত প্রান্তর'' (2006)<ref>{{cite news |last=Alamgir |first=Rohini |date=28 July 2005 |title=Aguntok-3: Third time lucky or unlucky? |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/rising/2005/07/04/scr01.htm |newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref>
==Videography== Artcell has done music videos of some of their greatest hit song. They have eight music videos. * "অলস সময়ের পাড়ে (Lazy Time Shifts)" * "বাংলাদেশ...স্মৃতি ও আমরা (Bangladesh...Memories and Us)" * "লীন (Leen)" * "পাথর বাগান (Stone Garden)" * "অন্য সময় (Other Time)" * "ধুসর সময় (Gray Time)" * "অবিমৃষ্যতা (Ingenuity)" * "অদেখা স্বর্গ (Unseen Heaven)" <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SngCypnmLx0 |title=Odekha Shorgo Music Video by Artcell |website=YouTube}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* FDA approval of Truvada for PrEP */HTTP → HTTPS for [[Food and Drug Administration]], replaced: http://www.fda.gov/ → https://www.fda.gov/
revision.text:
[[File:IPrEx logo.png|thumb|alt=iPrEx logo |iPrEx logo]] '''{{lowercase}}iPrEx''' (from {{lang-es|Iniciativa Profilaxis Pre-Exposición}}, "[[pre-exposure prophylaxis]] initiative") was a phase III [[clinical trial]] to determine whether the [[antiretroviral]] medication [[emtricitabine/tenofovir]] (as [[tenofovir disoproxil|tenofovir disoproxil fumarate]]) could safely and effectively prevent [[HIV]] acquisition through sex in men who have sex with men and transgender women. iPrEx was the first human study of an HIV prevention strategy known as pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP.{{cite web |publisher=iPrEx OLE |url=http://www.iprexole.com/1pages/prep/prep-whatistheiprexstudy.php |title=What is the iPrEx study? |accessdate=1 July 2013 }} The study began in 2007 at four study sites in [[Peru]] and [[Ecuador]], following three years of extensive community and stakeholder consultation. In 2008 the study expanded to seven additional sites in [[Brazil]], [[South Africa]], [[Thailand]] and the [[United States]]. ==Study sponsors== iPrEx was sponsored by the US [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH) through a grant to the Gladstone Institutes, a non-profit independent research organization affiliated to the [[University of California at San Francisco]]. Additional support for the conduct of the study was provided by the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]].ClinicalTrials.gov (http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00458393?term=iprex&rank=2). Retrieved 1 July 2013. Study medication was donated by [[Gilead Sciences]] Inc. ==Study design== iPrEx was an interventional double-blind, placebo controlled trial of the safety and efficacy of the once-daily antiretroviral medication emtricitabine/tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (FTC/TDF) as pre-exposure prophylaxis for the prevention of HIV acquisition in sexually active gay and bisexual men and transgender women who have sex with men. The study enrolled 2,499 HIV uninfected participants at 11 study sites in six countries on four continents. These participants attended monthly visits to receive a bottle of study medication with supply for 30 days. Half of the study participants received an experimental PrEP pill (Truvada) and the other half received [[placebo]]. Participants also received additional HIV prevention services to help reduce their risk of contracting HIV. These included [[Diagnosis of HIV/AIDS|HIV testing]], [[safer sex]] counseling, treatment of [[sexually transmitted infections]] and provision of [[condoms]]. ===Demographics=== The distribution of study participation by site and country is as follows:Grant, RM et al. Preexposure Chemoprophylaxis for HIV Prevention in Men WhoHave Sex with Men (23 November 2010) (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1011205) Retrieved 1 July 2013. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="5" style="background-color: #CCEEEE;" | Geographical Demographics of IPrEx Recruitment |- ! country ! study sites ! percentage of participants ! notes |- | [[United States]] | [[Fenway Health]] ([[Boston]])
[[San Francisco Department of Public Health]] ([[San Francisco]]) | 9% | |- | [[Ecuador]] | [[Fundación Ecuatoriana Equidad]] ([[Guayaquil]]) | 12% | |- | [[Peru]] | [[Asociacion Civil Selva Amazonica]] ([[Iquitos]])
[[Asociación Civil Impacta Salud y Educación]] ([[Lima]])
[[Investigaciones Medicas en Salud]] (Lima) | 55% | |- | [[Brazil]] | [[Evandro Chagas Institute]]
[[Oswaldo Cruz Foundation]] ([[Rio de Janeiro]])
[[Projecto Praca Onze]] (Rio de Janeiro)
[[University of São Paulo]] ([[São Paulo]]) | 15% | |- | [[Thailand]] | [[Research Institute for Health Sciences]] ([[Chiang Mai]]) | 5% | |- | [[South Africa]] | [[Desmond Tutu HIV Foundation]] ([[Cape Town]]) | 4% | |- |total | |100% | |} ==Study results== The iPrEx study started in June 2007 and concluded in February 2011. Preliminary study results were published in the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'' on 23 November 2010. Participants were followed for a median of 21 months. The average age of study participants was 24. Of the 2,499 participants, 1,251 were randomly assigned to Truvada and 1,248 were assigned to take the placebo tablet (sugar pill). There were 36 HIV infections among the participants who were offered Truvada and 64 among those offered placebo, meaning that Truvada PrEP provided 44% additional protection against HIV in this group. This efficacy analysis (a modified [[intention-to-treat analysis]]) includes those study participants who received active study drug but who did not take it regularly enough for the drug to have any protective effect. Protection against HIV infection was significantly higher among iPrEx study participants who took the drug regularly enough to have detectable drug concentrations in their systems, as measured through [[blood analysis]]. Among participants whose blood analyses indicated that they took PrEP 7 days a week, HIV acquisition risk was reduced by 99%. Among those who took the drug 4 days a week, the risk of HIV acquisition was reduced by 96%.Anderson, PL, Emtricitabine-Tenofovir Concentrations and Pre-Exposrue Prophylaxis Efficacy in Men Who Have Sex with Men (12 September 2012) (http://stm.sciencemag.org/content/4/151/151ra125.full.html) Retrieved 1 July 2013. Due to the positive results, the study expanded to follow up participants for 72 weeks in an open label extension phase (see iPrEx OLE, below). ==Response to results== ===Popular media=== On the day of announcement of iPrEx study results, the [[President of the United States]], [[Barack Obama]], welcomed the outcomes of the study.White House, NIH-Funded Study Finds Daily Dose of Antiretroviral Drug Reduces Risk of HIV (23 November 2010) (http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/11/23/nih-funded-study-finds-daily-dose-antiretroviral-drug-reduces-risk-hiv) Retrieved 1 July 2013. The U.S. news magazine ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' called the iPrEx results the most significant medical breakthrough of 2010.Park, Alice (9 December 2010) (http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2035319_2034529,00.html) Retrieved 1 July. 2013. ===CDC interim guidance=== In January 2011, the US [[Centers for Disease Control]] and Prevention issued interim guidance for the provision of PrEP to prevent sexual acquisition of HIV among men who have sex with men.CDC Interim Guidance on HIV PrEP for Men Who Have Sex with Men (https://www.cdc.gov/nchhstp/newsroom/2011/PrEPMSMGuidanceGraphic.html) Retrieved 30 December 2016. *Truvada is the only PrEP to have been tested * PrEP is only for the HIV-negative * PrEP is an additional defense against HIV alongside other options including the following: **Use condoms **Get HIV tested regularly **Get tested for other [[sexually transmitted infections]] **Get [[harm reduction]] education **Reduce one's number of sexual partners * PrEP has been shown to be effective for those taking it daily and ineffective for people who forget or skip doses ===International Partnership for Microbicides=== The [[International Partnership for Microbicides]] issued a statement by founder [[Zeda Rosenberg]] saying that "The hard work and dedication of the iPrEx team and trial participants has led to a second successful proof-of-concept this year for an ARV-based HIV-prevention product. We must not falter at this important time in history when science shows us that, with sufficient resolve, we can begin to control and potentially reverse the HIV epidemic."{{cite web |url=http://www.ipmglobal.org/publications-media/iprex-clinical-trial-demonstrates-44-protection-against-hiv |title=iPrEx Clinical Trial Demonstrates 44 Percent Protection Against HIV - Mounting Evidence of the Power of ARVs to Prevent HIV Transmission |author=Zeda Rosenberg |date=23 Nov 2011 |website= |publisher=[[International Partnership for Microbicides]] |accessdate=6 February 2011}} ===FDA approval of Truvada for PrEP=== On 27 August 2012, the US Food and Drug Administration approved the use of Truvada as PrEP for sexually active adults, based on the results of two clinical trials: iPrEx and PartnersPrEP.FDA, FDA Approves firstdrug for reduction the risk of sexually acquired HIV infection (16 July 2012)(https://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm312210.htm) Retrieved 1 July 2013. ==iPrEx OLE== {{unreferenced|section|date=June 2019}} [[File:IPrEx OLE logo.jpg|right|thumb|183x183px|iPrEx OLE logo]] iPrEx OLE (OLE stands for [[Open-label trial|Open Label Extension]]) is a continuation of the iPrEx study designed to provide additional information about the safety of PrEP and the behavior of people taking PrEP over a longer term, including information on: *Long-term efficacy *Long-term safety *Pill taking and adherence *Any changes in participants’ sexual behavior *Drug resistance *Bone mineral density and fat distribution *Impact on hepatitis infection It is hoped that participants’ knowledge that Truvada PrEP is safe and effective for HIV infection, and that no placebo is used in the study, will lead to increased use of the study drug and increased protection against HIV infection among in iPrEx OLE participants. iPrEx OLE started enrollment on 13 June 2011 at the San Francisco Department of Public Health in California, USA and closed enrollment in July 2012 at Investigaciones Medicas en Salud in Lima, Peru. All participants enrolled in the first phase of the iPrEx study were invited to continue in the Open Label Extension. Through iPrEx OLE, all HIV-negative study participants who choose to take it receive daily oral PrEP with Truvada. HIV-positive study participants receive regular medical monitoring and other services through iPrEx OLE, but do not receive the study drug, which is designed to prevent HIV infection. iPrEx OLE enrolled 1770 participants at 11 sites in six countries. Of all participants enrolled in iPrEx OLE, 1,129 (63.8%) chose the "on-PrEP" track and 473 (26.7%) elected to be "off-PrEP". There are 168 (9.5%) seropositive participants enrolled in the open label extension. Results from this open label extension phase of the study are expected by the first quarter of 2014. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT00458393 clinicaltrials.gov entry] {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} [[Category:Clinical trials related to HIV]] [[Category:Clinical trials sponsored by NIAID]]

It stars actor [[Gabriele Ferzetti]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mymovies.it/filmografia/?a=73|title=Gabriele Ferzetti |publisher=[[Mymovies.it]]|accessdate=November 30, 2010}} The script was co-written by [[Lucio Fulci]].Thrower, Stephen (1999). Beyond Terror, the Films of Lucio Fulci. FAB Press. pag 282. == Plot == A group of likeable slackers with little talent attempts to steal a prestigious jewellery collection exhibited at the highest floor of a tower. What they lack in experience, they make up for with street smarts. They think the stakes are too high for them, so they subcontract the heist, but swindle the subcontractor. They try to blackmail the exhibition's insurance agency, but end up tricked. == Cast == * [[Michel Bouquet]] as Albert * [[Serge Reggiani]] as Pierrot * [[Marcel Bozzuffi]] as Gus * [[Dany Carrel]] as Lulu * [[Victor Lanoux]] as Gino * [[Gabriele Ferzetti]] as Raphaël * [[Françoise Rosay]] as Mme Dubreuil * [[Bernard Fresson]] as Julien * [[Amidou]] as José * [[Nike Arrighi]] as Minouche * [[Pierre Rousseau]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=|title=Sette cervelli per un colpo perfetto}} [[Category:1972 films]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French heist films]] [[Category:Italian heist films]] [[Category:1970s heist films]] {{1970s-France-film-stub}} {{1970s-Italy-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Ole Carlson House | nrhp_type = | image = 2010-1025-OleCarlsonHouse.jpg | caption = | nearest_city= [[Kasson, Minnesota]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|57|16|N|92|41|52|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Minnesota#USA | built = 1880 | architect = Aasved, Ole Anderson | architecture = | added = April 16, 1982 | area = less than one acre | governing_body = Private | mpsub = {{NRHP url|id=64000351|title=Dodge County MRA}} | refnum = 82002944<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }}
The '''Ole Carlson House''' is a historic [[farmhouse]] in [[Dodge County, Minnesota]]. Located in [[Canisteo Township, Dodge County, Minnesota|Canisteo Township]], it is on County Road 15, approximately {{convert|8|mi}} south of [[Kasson, Minnesota]]. In 1981, the home remained in the ownership of the grandson and great-grandson of Ole Carlson. The private home was placed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] (NRHP) on April 16, 1982.<ref name=MHPIF/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://landmarkhunter.com/155564-ole-carlson-house/|title=Ole Carlson House|publisher =LandmarkHunter.com|accessdate= February 20, 2016}}</ref>
==Structure== [[File:Olecarlsonslide.jpg|thumb|left|The Ole Carlson House, not long after its construction. Note the existence of [[balustrade]] and lack of plantings.]]
The Ole Carlson House was both designed and built by Ole Anderson Aasved for his neighbor Ole Carlson, a fellow [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] immigrant farmer. Its location on a slight elevation makes the structure very visible. The house is a large, two-story, almost square brick structure, symmetrical in arrangement with a [[hip roof]] and roof deck, with a projecting central [[gable]]d pavilion. At the time the home was completed, it had a [[balustrade]] along the edge of the roof deck, however it is no longer present. In addition to the main house, a small one-story brick addition on the eastern side (rear) houses a [[Kitchen#Colonial American kitchens|summer kitchen]]. The south foundation includes a [[datestone]] with the name "O. A. Aasved" and the date "1880".<ref name=MHPIF>Robert M. Frame III, Minnesota Historic Properties Inventory Form, June 5, 1981.</ref>
The design includes elements reminiscent of the [[Italianate architecture|Italianate style]], which are often found in rural Minnesota farmhouses of the era and used to emphasize verticality. These elements include two-over-two double-hung [[sash windows]] in tall rectangular openings with [[Keystone (architecture)|keystone]] segmental-arch hoods, and hooded double front entrance. Unlike similar houses, conventional [[eave]] [[Bracket (architecture)|brackets]] were never applied to the house.<ref name=MHPIF/>
==History== The builder, Ole Anderson Aasved, was born in March 1826 near [[Trondheim]], [[Norway]]. Raised on a farm, he had almost no formal education, but he sought to educate himself. Aasved was married several times. He married Christiana Anderson in 1849, and the couple had one child, Christiana (later Mrs. Martin Peterson), before his wife died in 1854. Aasved moved to the United States in 1857, and in 1860 he married fellow Norwegian native Ingred Alexson; they had one daughter, Anna, before Alexson died in 1869. He worked in logging Michigan before settling in Minnesota. In 1865 he enlisted in the [[2nd Minnesota Volunteer Cavalry Regiment]] of the [[Union Army]], but saw no active service and was discharged in the same year.<ref name=CtyHistory1884>H.A. Smith, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=41FKAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1104&lpg=PA1104 The History of Winona, Olmsted and Dodge County]'', H.H. Hill and Company, p. 1104.</ref>
[[File:OleCarlsonPlatt.jpg|thumb|right|The 1905 [[plat]] map of the "Ole Karlson" properties and their acreage in the township. The small black box shows the location of the house.]]
In Minnesota, Aasved accumulated {{convert|220|acres}} of land in adjacent {{convert|140|acres}} and {{convert|80|acres}} parcels. Aasved finished his own residence in 1882 at a cost of $3,000. In 1883 he married a third time, to fellow Norwegian immigrant Benedicka Hanson.<ref name=CtyHistory1884/>
==Significance== The Ole Carlson House was selected for placement on the NRHP based on its significance to the agricultural history of the Upper Midwest, its own unique architecture, and as an example of the ethnic settlements of early [[Norwegian American]]s. A county history of 1884 declared that the house was "the best farm house in the county."<ref name=MHPIF/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{National Register of Historic Places}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carlson, Ole, House}} [[Category:Houses on the National Register of Historic Places in Minnesota]] [[Category:Houses completed in 1880]] [[Category:Houses in Dodge County, Minnesota]] [[Category:Norwegian-American culture in Minnesota]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Dodge County, Minnesota]]
